text: Is this with bounds checking enabled or disabled?

elements.text: Is this with bounds checking enabled or disabled?

text:
starting julia with `--check-bounds=no`:
```julia> bench()
only_bench:
  2.454 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
one_idx_bench:
  1.369 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
deref_bench:
  1.369 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
first_bench:
  1.408 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
twod_one_idx_bench:
  1.369 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
splat_bench:

end_bench:
  1.369 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
begin_end_bench:

reduce_sum_bench:

unsafe_bench:
  1.369 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
starwars_bench:
  1.751 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```

text: I wonder if --`checkbounds=no`   should prevent `only` from checking there isn’t too many elements?

elements.text: from checking there isn’t too many elements?

text: Nah. Why would you use only if you are skipping the check anyway?

elements.text: Nah. Why would you use only if you are skipping the check anyway?

text:
with `--check-bounds=no` they all compile to the same code, including `cispi` (and actually including `starwars`, why is it slower? :confused:), that's incredible:
```julia> @code_native debuginfo=:none starwars_bench(x)
        .text
        movq    (%rdi), %rax
        vmovsd  (%rax), %xmm0                   # xmm0 = mem[0],zero
        retq
        nopl    (%rax,%rax)

julia> @code_native debuginfo=:none unsafe_bench(x)
        .text
        movq    (%rdi), %rax
        vmovsd  (%rax), %xmm0                   # xmm0 = mem[0],zero
        retq
        nopl    (%rax,%rax)

julia> @code_native debuginfo=:none cispi_bench(x)
        .text
        movq    (%rdi), %rax
        vmovsd  (%rax), %xmm0                   # xmm0 = mem[0],zero
        retq
        nopl    (%rax,%rax)```
